entry.title: BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_TT does not show errors if no stock available (nor COGI!?)

entry.title: Re: How are MT940 Transaction Keys Mapped to External Transaction Keys in SAP Bank Statement Process
entry.content:
Hello @MalgorzataS,

Thanks for the response,

Suppose my bank statement (attached) uses field 61 as the transaction key. My requirement is to have separate G/L accounts for:

  • Incoming bank transfer

  • Incoming cheque

  • Outgoing transfer

  • Outgoing cheque

I have created four external transaction keys in SAP for these scenarios and defined the corresponding posting (processing) rules.

My question:
How does SAP determine which external transaction code is mapped to a specific transaction from the bank statement file? For example, how does SAP know whether a transaction in field 61 should be posted using the external key for incoming transfer or outgoing cheque? Is the mapping entirely based on configuration, or does SAP use logic from the MT940 file‚Äôs content (like amount sign or code combinations)? What setup or mapping is required to ensure each transaction is posted to the correct G/L account?

Any clarification on the technical flow or config steps for this mapping would be helpful.

Best Regards,

Nithin

entry.title: Re: HR Access to Performance Forms
entry.content:
Hi - We permissioned reporting. This is the path for our HR colleagues to access in progress or completed forms:

Report Center > Classic Reporting > All Reports by Type > Detailed Document Search

The Detail Document Search results allow you to Generate Report as a read-only version of the form. Traditional excel exports are also available.

entry.title: Re: SF LMS Item Completion Rule for Assignment Profile
entry.content: Sorry @karenperez.  My experience shows that, in the current release,  the required operator for Item Completion is EQUALS. However, in some cases SuccessFactors changes this to MATCHES when you save the rules. This is a known issue acc. to Copilot. One workaround iIfound is to go back and copy one of your APs that works: copy everything including the item. Then, in the copy, swap out the item for the new desired one. Save the rules. That can sometimes preserve your EQUALS operator. I hope that SAP is trying to fix this üòû .

entry.title: Re: Search for the BAdI to trigger a notification after s...
entry.content: Hi, is this BADI released? Ideally, the approach for this would be to use local/remote event consumption. However, currently in S4 2023, local event consumption is only supported for custom RAP BOs. The released events for standard RAP BOs cannot be consumed directly via local event consumption.

entry.title: Recommendations requested: Training Item Organization
entry.content:
We have three modules of internally-developed L&D trainings, which are optional for employees to take. Each module is set up as a curriculum, and we have both in-person and virtual versions of each curriculum. Each module contains 4-6 separate learning items within it.

This was all developed and implemented before my time, but I've been tasked with cleaning up our LMS. We want to be able to streamline the presentation of these modules, ideally just having one instance of each module that contains all content for folks to register for whether they are attending virtually or in-person. Additionally, we'd like to be able to present Module 1 to everyone on the new learning home page as "important learning," but make modules 2 and 3 searchable by all employees. What is the best recommendation for how to do so?

Happy to answer questions and provide additional context/clarification. Thanks in advance for any support!

entry.title: SAP Build Apps Redirects to Initial Page in Work Zone on Browser Refresh
entry.content:
SAP Build Apps Redirects to Initial Page in Work Zone on Browser Refresh

 

Hello Community,

I am experiencing an issue with state management and routing when running an SAP Build Apps application deployed within SAP Build Work Zone Standard Edition (Trial Account).

Configuration and Setup:

  1. I created and deployed an SAP Build Apps application on sap build Work zone.

  2. In the Work Zone, I updated the Channel Manager and added the HTML5 Application in the content mange and then added it to my catalog. 

The Problem:

The application launches correctly from the tile and operates as expected. However, the application appears to be running without proper URL routing synchronization with the Work Zone shell:

  • When I navigate to a secondary page within the Build App, the URL in the browser address bar remains unchanged.

  • Consequently, if I perform a browser refresh (F5) while on a secondary page, the application redirects back to the application's initial/Home Page.

entry.title: Ariba Sourcing: how to send prices to external system when Unit Price has more than 2 decimals?
entry.content:
We are currently facing an issue related to unit price precision in a sourcing event in SAP Ariba.

In our current setup, some materials have a unit price defined with 4 decimal places (e.g., 0.1234 EUR per piece). This level of precision is important for business accuracy. However, SAP S/4HANA only accepts unit prices with a maximum of 2 decimal places, which causes the integration between Ariba and S/4HANA to fail when processing such sourcing events and generating contracts.

In the past (before using SAP Ariba), this was resolved by defining the price in contract in SAP S/4 HANA for 100 pieces instead of 1, allowing for a price like 12.34 EUR per 100 pcs, which works within S/4HANA‚Äôs limits.

Our understanding is that there is no standard functionality or recommended workaround that would allow us to collect prices per 1 piece in SAP Ariba and 4 decimal and have an award sent to SAP S/4 HANA with price per 100 pieces and 2 decimals.

For that reason we are exploring a solution where price per 100 pieces is collected in SAP Ariba so that later award can be sent to external system and we can have a contract creates in SAP S/4 HANA with price per 100 pieces.

For example: price per 1 piece is 0.4455 EUR.  Overall quantity is 100 000 pieces.
So our only option would be to ask supplier in Ariba for price for 100 pieces (in this example it would be 44.55 EUR and it would be accepted by SAP S/4HANA). 
So after award we could send prices to external system to create a quantity contract for 100 000 pieces with price  44.55 per 100 pieces. 

Is possible to configure SAP Ariba event so that the above would be possible? If so, how can this be done?
Do you have any other suggestions on how this should be addressed?

entry.title: Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application
entry.content:
Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application and Integrating with SAP Build Work Zone

In this tutorial, we will guide you through the process of creating a custom Joule skill tailored to a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) based Fiori application. You‚Äôll learn how to deploy this skill and enable Joule functionality within SAP Build Work Zone, enabling intelligent, conversational interaction within your enterprise apps.

Step 1: Configure a Destination in Your SAP BTP Subaccount

Begin by setting up a destination in your SAP BTP subaccount where Joule Studio is subscribed. This destination should point to the endpoint of your CAP service.

Ensure you add the following property in the additional settings:

sap.processautomation.enabled = true

 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true

 

sap.build.usage = CAP

This configuration allows SAP Build to consume the service.

 

Step 2: Add Destination in the Control Tower

Next, go to the Control Tower section within the SAP Build Process Automation cockpit and add the destination you just created.

 

Step 3: Start a New Action Project

Navigate to the Actions tab and click Create to initiate a new action project.

 

Step 4: Choose SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

Since your action will interact with a CAP service, select SAP Cloud Application Programming Model as the project type.

 

Step 5: Select and Configure Service Endpoints

  • A list of available service endpoints from your CAP application will be displayed. Pick the desired endpoint and complete the necessary configuration.

 

  • Click on Next
  • Give You Project Name

 

 

  • Create Action for the ODATA Service
  • Select required endpoint and configure it.

  

 

  • Test the Endpoint with destination and see the output

 

 

  • Create similar action for the all department data and test it

 

 

 

Step 6: Build and Deploy Your Joule Skill

  • Click Create to set up the action project. Then, select the Joule Skill tile and create the skill

 

  • Open the above skill and again create joule skill and give name and description

 

  • Open he above skill and add action like below

 

  • Configure destination for this action

 

  • Configure the Output Variable for this action

 

  • Set the output variable on clicking on End
  • Create similar joule skill for department by following above steps

 

  • Once you finish, Save, Release

 

 

 

 

  • After Releasing Click on Deploy and choose the environment that you want

 

 

Step 7: Enable Shared Access

  • Go to home page and click on Control Tower
  • Choose Environment
  • Select Environment that we choose for our Joule Skill you will see your deployed skill there

 

 

  • Click on Setting and Enable shared option

Step 8: Connect Joule with SAP Build Work Zone

At the global account level, access the Formations area. Select Include Systems and add SAP Build Work Zone from the appropriate subaccount.

Activate these features:

  • Enable Joule Icon in Integrated System

 

Step 9: Confirm Integration and Activate Joule

Verify your setup under System Landscape ‚Üí Formation.

Then, log into your SAP Build Work Zone site.

Step 10: Validate Your Skills

Open your Work Zone site to see the Joule Icon appear at the top.

 

Test your deployed skill by typing queries related to your CAP application and observe how Joule responds.

 

 

 

Summary

Integrating custom Joule Skills into SAP Build Work Zone allows you to embed conversational AI directly within your business applications. This guide demonstrated how to connect a CAP-based Fiori app, configure necessary destinations, deploy custom skills, and enable Joule for seamless interaction.

By following these steps, you enable end users to engage naturally with enterprise data and processes‚Äîmaking your applications smarter, more interactive, and easier to use.

entry.title: Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution
entry.content:
Building the Future of Enterprise AI: MCP Servers and Agent-to-Agent Communication Revolution

Transforming how AI systems collaborate in modern enterprise environments

 

The enterprise AI landscape is experiencing a paradigm shift. While individual AI agents have proven their worth in specific domains, the real transformation happens when these intelligent systems can seamlessly collaborate, share knowledge, and coordinate complex workflows. Enter two revolutionary protocols that are reshaping how we think about AI integration: Model Context Protocol (MCP) and Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A).

The Integration Challenge: Breaking Down AI Silos

Picture this: You're managing an e-commerce platform with specialized AI agents for inventory management, fraud detection, customer recommendations, and order fulfillment. Each agent performs exceptionally within its domain, but when a customer wants to modify a large order that was flagged for unusual purchasing patterns while using a promotional code‚Äîsuddenly your streamlined system becomes a coordination nightmare.

This scenario illustrates the fundamental challenge facing modern enterprises: AI agents operating in isolation. Without standardized communication protocols, organizations struggle with:

  • Integration Complexity: Each new AI tool requires custom integration work, consuming valuable development resources
  • Data Inconsistency: Different systems use varying data formats, leading to translation errors and processing delays
  • Workflow Fragmentation: Multi-step processes require manual intervention to bridge gaps between AI systems
  • Scalability Limitations: Adding new capabilities means exponentially more integration points to maintain

The result? Expensive, brittle AI implementations that fail to deliver their full potential.

Model Context Protocol (MCP): The Universal AI Language

 

Model Context Protocol addresses the first half of this challenge by creating a standardized way for AI applications to communicate with external systems and data sources. Developed by Anthropic, MCP serves as a universal translator that eliminates the need for custom integrations.

How MCP Transforms System Integration

Traditional AI integration requires developers to:

  • Learn each system's unique API structure
  • Handle different authentication methods
  • Parse varying data formats
  • Maintain separate codebases for each integration

MCP changes this by providing a unified interface that abstracts away system-specific complexities. Think of it as having a universal remote control that works with every device in your smart home, regardless of brand or model.

Core MCP Components

MCP Host: Acts as the central coordination hub, managing all communication between AI clients and external systems.

MCP Client: Represents your AI application that needs to access external resources or capabilities.

MCP Server: Exposes specific functionalities, data sources, or services in a standardized format that any MCP client can understand.

What MCP Servers Provide

Tools: Executable functions that AI agents can discover and use dynamically. For example, a customer service AI could discover and invoke tools for order lookup, refund processing, or inventory checking without needing pre-programmed knowledge of each system.

Resources: Access to both static and dynamic data sources. This might include real-time inventory levels, customer databases, product catalogs, or analytical reports‚Äîall accessible through a consistent interface.

Prompts: Reusable, parameterized templates that maintain consistency across different AI interactions while allowing for customization based on specific contexts.

Real-World MCP Benefits: E-commerce Transformation

Consider an online retailer implementing MCP across their AI ecosystem:

Before MCP: Their recommendation engine needed separate integrations with the inventory system, customer database, pricing engine, and analytics platform. Each integration required months of development and ongoing maintenance.

After MCP: The recommendation engine simply queries the MCP ecosystem for "customer profile," "available products," and "pricing data." The MCP servers handle all the complexity of connecting to underlying systems, transforming data formats, and managing authentication.

Result: Development time reduced from months to weeks, maintenance overhead decreased by 60%, and new AI capabilities can be added without touching existing integrations.

MCP's Business Impact

Accelerated Development: Teams can focus on AI logic rather than integration plumbing, reducing time-to-market for new AI features by up to 70%.

Enhanced Reliability: Standardized interfaces reduce integration bugs and improve system stability.

Future-Proofing: When underlying systems change, only the MCP server needs updating‚Äîall connected AI clients continue working without modification.

Cost Efficiency: Reduced integration complexity means lower development and maintenance costs, with some organizations reporting 50% savings on AI infrastructure expenses.

Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A): Orchestrating AI Collaboration

 

While MCP solves the AI-to-system challenge, Agent-to-Agent Protocol tackles the equally important problem of AI-to-AI communication. A2A enables different AI agents to discover, communicate, and coordinate with each other to handle complex, multi-step workflows.

The Multi-Agent Coordination Challenge

Modern business processes rarely fit within a single AI agent's capabilities. Consider a customer support scenario where a client reports a billing error on their account. This seemingly simple request actually requires coordination between:

  • Customer Service AI: To understand the query and manage the interaction
  • Billing System AI: To identify and analyze the billing discrepancy
  • Fraud Detection AI: To ensure the request isn't part of a fraudulent pattern
  • Account Management AI: To determine appropriate remediation steps

Without A2A, each handoff between agents requires manual intervention or custom integration work.

A2A's Coordination Framework

Dynamic Discovery: Agents can automatically discover other agents' capabilities through standardized "Agent Cards" that describe what each agent can do, what inputs it needs, and what outputs it provides.

Role-Based Organization: A2A defines clear roles‚Äîcoordinators who manage workflows, specialists who handle specific tasks, and observers who monitor and provide insights.

Task Lifecycle Management: Every interaction follows a structured lifecycle from task creation through completion, with standardized status updates and error handling.

Flexible Communication: Agents can exchange various content types‚Äîtext, images, structured data, or complex multimedia‚Äîthrough a unified messaging framework.

Transformative Healthcare Use Case

Let's explore how A2A revolutionizes healthcare coordination‚Äîa domain where precise, timely collaboration literally saves lives:

Scenario: A patient arrives at the emergency department with chest pain.

Traditional Approach:

  • Triage nurse manually enters patient data into multiple systems
  • Various specialists are paged individually
  • Lab orders are placed through separate systems
  • Results are manually communicated between departments
  • Treatment decisions involve multiple phone calls and consultations

A2A-Enabled Approach: The Emergency Coordinator Agent automatically orchestrates the entire process:

  1. Immediate Assessment: Delegates initial evaluation to the Triage AI, which processes symptoms and assigns priority
  2. Parallel Specialist Coordination: Simultaneously engages Cardiology AI for cardiac risk assessment, Lab AI for stat blood work orders, and Radiology AI for imaging protocols
  3. Real-Time Collaboration: As results become available, each specialist AI provides recommendations that are automatically integrated into a comprehensive assessment
  4. Coordinated Decision Making: The Treatment Planning AI synthesizes all inputs to recommend optimal care pathways
  5. Resource Optimization: Bed Management AI ensures appropriate room assignment while Pharmacy AI prepares necessary medications

Outcome: What traditionally took hours of coordination happens in minutes, with improved accuracy and reduced human error.

A2A's Healthcare Benefits

Reduced Response Times: Emergency protocols that previously required 30-45 minutes now complete in under 10 minutes.

Improved Accuracy: Standardized communication eliminates transcription errors and ensures all relevant information is considered.

Enhanced Care Quality: Parallel processing allows for more comprehensive evaluation without delays.

Resource Optimization: Intelligent coordination prevents resource conflicts and optimizes staff utilization.

Audit Trail: Every decision and communication is logged, providing complete visibility into care processes.

The Synergy: MCP + A2A = Enterprise AI Excellence

The true power emerges when MCP and A2A work together, creating an ecosystem where AI agents can seamlessly access any enterprise system while coordinating sophisticated workflows with other agents.

Manufacturing Excellence Example

Consider a smart manufacturing facility where quality control, predictive maintenance, supply chain, and production planning agents work together:

MCP Integration: Each agent accesses manufacturing data through standardized interfaces‚Äîproduction metrics, equipment sensors, inventory levels, and quality reports‚Äîwithout needing to understand the underlying industrial systems.

A2A Coordination: When the predictive maintenance agent detects potential equipment failure, it automatically:

  • Alerts the production planning agent to adjust schedules
  • Informs the supply chain agent to expedite replacement parts
  • Notifies the quality control agent to increase inspection frequency
  • Coordinates with the facility management agent to schedule maintenance windows

Result: Unplanned downtime reduced by 80%, maintenance costs decreased by 40%, and product quality improved through proactive interventions.

Financial Services Transformation

In banking, compliance, risk management, customer service, and fraud detection agents collaborate to provide comprehensive financial services:

Real-Time Risk Assessment: When a customer applies for a loan, the application automatically triggers parallel processing across multiple AI agents‚Äîcredit analysis, fraud detection, regulatory compliance, and market risk assessment‚Äîwith results synthesized in minutes rather than days.

Automated Compliance: Regulatory changes automatically propagate through the agent network, with each agent updating its decision-making criteria and reporting mechanisms without human intervention.

Enhanced Customer Experience: Customer service agents can instantly access comprehensive customer profiles while coordinating with specialized agents for investment advice, loan modifications, or dispute resolution.

Strategic Implementation Benefits

Organizational Advantages

Scalability Without Complexity: Adding new AI capabilities becomes as simple as plugging in new agents‚Äîthe underlying infrastructure handles all communication and coordination automatically.

Reduced Technical Debt: Standardized protocols eliminate the accumulation of custom integrations that become expensive to maintain over time.

Faster Innovation: Teams can experiment with new AI agents without worrying about integration challenges, accelerating the pace of innovation.

Improved ROI: Organizations typically see 3x faster deployment of new AI capabilities and 60% reduction in integration costs.

Operational Excellence

Enhanced Reliability: Built-in error handling, circuit breakers, and failover mechanisms ensure system resilience even when individual components fail.

Better Visibility: Comprehensive monitoring and logging provide unprecedented insight into AI system performance and decision-making processes.

Simplified Management: Centralized configuration and monitoring reduce operational complexity while improving control over AI behaviors.

Compliance Readiness: Standardized audit trails and governance frameworks make it easier to meet regulatory requirements.

Addressing Implementation Challenges

Security and Trust Considerations

Authentication and Authorization: Both protocols include robust security frameworks to ensure only authorized agents can access specific resources or communicate with other agents.

Data Privacy: Built-in privacy controls protect sensitive information while enabling necessary collaboration between agents.

Audit and Compliance: Comprehensive logging and monitoring capabilities support regulatory requirements and internal governance policies.

Performance Optimization

Efficient Communication: Both protocols are designed for high-performance scenarios with minimal overhead and optimized message formats.

Load Balancing: Intelligent distribution of work across agent networks prevents bottlenecks and ensures optimal resource utilization.

Caching and Optimization: Smart caching mechanisms reduce redundant operations and improve overall system responsiveness.

Change Management

Gradual Adoption: Organizations can implement MCP and A2A incrementally, starting with high-value use cases and expanding over time.

Training and Education: Success requires investment in team education to help developers and administrators understand the new paradigms.

Cultural Shift: Moving from custom integrations to standardized protocols requires organizational commitment to new development approaches.

Future Outlook: The Evolution of AI Collaboration

Emerging Trends

Multi-Modal Communication: Next-generation implementations will support rich media communications, enabling agents to share images, video, audio, and complex data visualizations as part of their coordination efforts.

Federated Learning: Agents will be able to share and improve their models collaboratively while maintaining data privacy and security.

Self-Healing Networks: Advanced implementations will automatically detect and recover from failures, redistributing work and spawning replacement agents as needed.

Cross-Organization Collaboration: Future versions may enable secure collaboration between agents across organizational boundaries, creating industry-wide AI ecosystems.

Industry-Specific Evolution

Healthcare: Integration with medical devices, electronic health records, and regulatory systems will enable comprehensive patient care coordination.

Financial Services: Real-time market data integration and regulatory compliance automation will transform trading, lending, and risk management.

Manufacturing: Integration with IoT sensors, robotics, and supply chain systems will enable fully autonomous production optimization.

Retail: Seamless integration across online and offline channels will create truly omnichannel customer experiences.

Measuring Success: Key Performance Indicators

Technical Metrics

Integration Speed: Time to integrate new AI capabilities reduced from months to weeks

System Reliability: Uptime improvements of 99.9% or higher through robust error handling

Performance Optimization: Response time improvements of 40-60% through efficient communication protocols

Maintenance Reduction: 50-70% reduction in integration maintenance overhead

Business Metrics

Time to Market: Accelerated deployment of new AI features and capabilities

Cost Savings: Reduced development and maintenance costs through standardization

Innovation Velocity: Increased rate of AI experimentation and deployment

Competitive Advantage: Enhanced ability to respond quickly to market changes and opportunities

Getting Started: Practical Implementation Steps

Phase 1: Assessment and Planning

Current State Analysis: Evaluate existing AI implementations and identify integration pain points

Use Case Prioritization: Select high-value scenarios where MCP and A2A can deliver immediate benefits

Technical Readiness: Assess infrastructure and team capabilities for protocol implementation

Phase 2: Pilot Implementation

Limited Scope Deployment: Start with a single, well-defined use case to prove value and learn lessons

Performance Baseline: Establish metrics for comparing before and after implementation results

Team Training: Invest in education and skill development for development and operations teams

Phase 3: Scaled Deployment

Gradual Expansion: Systematically extend implementation to additional use cases and systems

Governance Framework: Establish policies and procedures for managing the expanded AI ecosystem

Continuous Optimization: Regular performance review and optimization of agent interactions and system performance

Conclusion: The Collaborative AI Future

The integration of Model Context Protocol and Agent-to-Agent Protocol represents a fundamental shift in how we architect and deploy enterprise AI systems. By standardizing communication between AI and enterprise systems (MCP) and enabling sophisticated coordination between AI agents (A2A), organizations can unlock the full potential of collaborative artificial intelligence.

The transformation is profound:

  • Development cycles shortened from months to weeks
  • Maintenance overhead reduced by 50-70%
  • System reliability improved to 99.9%+ uptime
  • Innovation velocity increased by 3x or more

The opportunity is immediate:

  • Protocols are mature and ready for enterprise deployment
  • Implementation can begin with high-value, low-risk pilot projects
  • Benefits compound as more agents and systems join the ecosystem

The competitive advantage is significant:

  • Organizations that adopt these protocols will be able to deploy AI capabilities faster and more reliably than competitors
  • The ability to coordinate complex, multi-agent workflows will become a key differentiator
  • Standardized approaches will enable innovation at unprecedented scale

Whether you're in healthcare, finance, manufacturing, or retail, MCP and A2A provide the foundation for building sophisticated, resilient, and scalable AI ecosystems that can transform how your organization operates and competes.

The future of enterprise AI isn't about individual agents working in isolation‚Äîit's about orchestrated networks of specialized agents working together seamlessly to deliver exceptional business outcomes. Start your journey toward collaborative AI excellence today.

Key Resources:

  • Strategic Planning: Begin with a comprehensive assessment of your current AI landscape and identify high-value integration opportunities
  • Technical Implementation: Consider partnering with experienced system integrators who understand both protocols
  • Change Management: Invest in team education and organizational change management to ensure successful adoption
  • Continuous Improvement: Plan for ongoing optimization and expansion of your collaborative AI ecosystem

entry.title: Clarification on Category Logic in SAP SuccessFactors LMS
entry.content:
Hello,

We would like to request clarification regarding the business logic recommended by SAP for the use of training categories within the Learning Management System (LMS) module of SuccessFactors.

Context:

  • We have implemented a category hierarchy (Level 1, Level 2, Level 3).
  • We have observed the following:
    • The hierarchy is not reflected in the front office filters (New Learning Experience) - As well communicated by SuccessFactors.
    • When exporting training categories, the values appear to be extracted without respecting the hierarchical order (Level 1 ‚Üí Level 2 ‚Üí Level 3).
    • The "Parent Category ID" field exists but does not seem to be leveraged in filters or default exports.

Main Question:

  • Should we only assign the lowest-level nodes of the hierarchy (e.g., Level 3) to training items, or is it recommended to also include intermediate levels (Level 1 and Level 2)?
  • What is the business logic promoted by SAP so that our client can align with best practices?

Objective:

We aim to ensure a consistent and optimized use of categories, both for user navigation and for reporting and exports.
Additionally, we want to ensure that our configuration is future-proof and compatible with upcoming SAP SuccessFactors evolutions, particularly regarding filters, reporting, and user interfaces.

Thank you in advance for your guidance.

Best regards,
Jeff Kellerhals

entry.title: Re: Customized fields at Case management of FSCM
entry.content:
Hi Prashant,

Please see below steps to debugg.

First we need to update the values in UKM_DCD_ATTR table using BADI - UKM_DCD_MAINTAIN~MAINTAIN.

1) Go to SE38 and keep the external break point for user 'SAP_WFRT', not your own user id.
 2) Go to class 'CL_UKM_DCD_WF_EVENT', click on display, put the break point in method - BI_EVENT_HANDLER_STATIC~ON_EVENT.
3) Go to class method ->cl_ukm_xi_facade=>if_ukm_dcd_push-push_dcd  ( line no 56 ).
4) BADI 'UKM_DCD_MAINTAIN' gets triggered after sales order saved and DB updates.

  Update the structure cs_add_attributes-CMNGV1 value then table UKM_DCD_ATTR gets updated.

Thank You,

Srini.

entry.title: Re: Retrieve the task list operations for a specific mate...
entry.content:
This should be enough to get you started. You were not using the node and counter fields (PLNKN,ZAEHL) that define activities.

 

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZZCV_CA03_001'

@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true

@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED

@EndUserText.label: 'Recreate CA03'

define view ZZCV_CA03

as

select from mapl

inner join plko on plko.plnty = mapl.plnty

and plko.plnnr = mapl.plnnr

and plko.plnal = mapl.plnal

and plko.zaehl = mapl.zaehl

inner join plas on plas.plnty = plko.plnty

and plas.plnnr = plko.plnnr

and plas.plnal = plko.plnal

inner join plpo on plpo.plnty = plas.plnty

and plpo.plnnr = plas.plnnr

and plpo.plnkn = plas.plnkn

and plpo.zaehl = plas.zaehl

inner join crhd on crhd.objty = 'A' //Work Center

and crhd.objid = plpo.arbid

{

mapl.matnr,

mapl.werks,

mapl.plnnr,

mapl.plnal,

plas.plnfl,

plpo.vornr,

crhd.arbpl

} where mapl.plnty = 'N' -- Routing

entry.title: What is Adoption?
entry.content:
As a former customer turned SAP employee dedicated to adoption, I hear some very different ideas about what adoption actually is.  It seems to mean something very different to almost every customer I‚Äôve spoken with (over 100 at this point)!  So let‚Äôs clear the fog and attempt to create a working definition of adoption!

_______________________________________________________________

First, What Adoption Is Not

  • Not just the starting line. Marathon running for instance involves preparation, a starting line, a finish line, and in between a lot of hard work. Similarly, the day you ‚Äúgo live‚Äù is the starting line, not the finish line. You have to run the entire race!
  • Not ‚Äúour users seem happy.‚Äù Sentiment is helpful but measurable business outcomes are the stuff of gold medals.
  • Not just a dashboard of random metrics. 1,000 logins are great but 3 automated processes that cut cycle time in half are better.
  • Not a once-and-done project. As your business, your processes, and your roadmap evolve; adoption is a continuous discipline.

_______________________________________________________________

So‚Ä¶ What Is Adoption?

Adoption is the strategic, ongoing process of turning your SAP software into everyday business results. It goes beyond initial deployment to drive full, meaningful engagement across your organization‚Äîso you realize the value you bought, renew with confidence, and double-down on what works. Let‚Äôs review adoption as three components.

1) Depth and Breadth of Usage

Great adoption means your team uses the right capabilities deeply‚Äîand enough teams use them broadly‚Äîto create enterprise-wide impact.

  • Depth: You‚Äôre not just approving POs or reviewing timesheets‚Äîyou‚Äôre using game- changing features like Guided Buying for SAP Ariba or SOW Bid for SAP Fieldglass. The features & functions that move the needle are the ones tied to specific value drivers such as price reduction, efficiency, quality, and compliance.
  • Breadth: Procurement, Finance, Operations, HR, and field teams all participate making workflows across what was once a silo‚Äôd organization. Swivel chair processes are gone. Handoffs are digital, not manual.

Signs you‚Äôre winning:

  • Feature usage moves from ‚Äúcore‚Äù capabilities to advanced.
  • Multiple business areas participate in end‚Äëto‚Äëend workflows (not isolated tasks).
  • Efficiency metrics improve: cycle time ‚Üì, rework ‚Üì, compliance ‚Üë.

Benefit: Your process becomes a case study in total transformation not just another software deployment.

2) Consumption Aligned to Entitlement

You‚Äôve matched what you own (spend/users/modules) with what you actually use‚Äîso value is realized, not left on the table.

  • You avoid shelfware by activating high‚Äëvalue modules you‚Äôve already paid for (and most likely justified with a business case).
  • Usage equals value. Your consumption patterns justify renewals and make the case for expansion.

Signs you‚Äôre winning:

  • License utilization aligns with the contract & business need.
  • Shelfware is activated with a plan.
  • Stakeholders can see a clear story of investing ‚Äúx‚Äù to get ‚Äúy‚Äù.

Benefit: The ROI is predictable & justified from a budget perspective because results are tangible.

3) Value Achieved

Adoption is measured by business results, not just the number of logins.

  • Efficiency: cycle time, touchless processing.
  • Compliance: policy adherence and audit readiness.
  • Cost/price: realized savings and cost avoidance.
  • Quality: candidates for SAP Fieldglass are up to the challenge

Signs you‚Äôre winning:

  • KPIs tie to executive priorities.
  • Value is repeatable and attributable to specific SAP-enabled scenarios.
  • Leaders want to know, ‚ÄúWhat else can we automate?‚Äù

Benefit: SAP solutions become an engine for transformation and growth. SAP is a valued and trusted partner.

_______________________________________________________________

A Practical 90‚ÄëDay Adoption Game Plan

  1. Start with value. Identify 3‚Äì5 outcomes (e.g., reduce invoice cycle time by 30%, increase spend under management by 15%).
  2. Map value to capability. Which capabilities make those outcomes real? (e.g., SAP Fieldglass Rate guidance or SOW bids.  SAP Ariba Guided Buying, a well-defined supplier risk process.)
  3. Activate champions by role. Procurement, AP, HR, and Operations, each need a champion with a playbook and a plan.
  4. Configure KPIs & measure them early so you can see adoption in real time.
  5. Show the score. Publish a simple, clear scorecard; spotlight improvements and highlight bottlenecks.
  6. Scale what works. Turn the first wins into success stories; communicate and repeat what works across teams/regions.
  7. Run regular adoption health checks. Which areas of the business need more help? Who deserves an innovation award?

_______________________________________________________________

Adoption done right . . .

So how are you running the race of adoption? Does your preparation phase need help? Do you need help getting from mile 13 to 20? When adoption is done right, your SAP solutions become the way your business runs‚Äîfaster, smarter, with endurance & purpose.

entry.title: Introducing My Metrics: Your Personalized view of Metrics in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
In a world overflowing with data, the real challenge isn't just finding information, it's keeping a constant pulse on the numbers that truly matter. Business leaders, analysts, and decision-makers often find themselves navigating through multiple dashboards and reports just to track their most critical metrics. The process can be time-consuming and fragmented.

Today, we're thrilled to change that. We are excited to announce My Metrics, a powerful new innovation in SAP Analytics Cloud for the 2025 Q4 QRC release, designed to simplify how you monitor, analyze, and share your most important business metrics.

What is My Metrics?

At its core, My Metrics is your personalized, curated collection of metrics that matter most to you and your business. It‚Äôs a central "watchlist" where you can gather vital metrics from various stories and models into one intuitive, easy-to-access space.

Imagine having a single screen where you can see your division's revenue, the conversion rate from your latest marketing campaign, and your team's customer satisfaction score, all updated in real-time, without having to open three different stories. That's the power of My Metrics.

Get Started With My Metrics

With My Metrics, you can build a personalized list to track the metrics that matter most to you. Arrange all your Metrics into categorized lists, making it easy to spot trends and understand your data at a glance.

My Metrics is introduced as a new module within SAP Analytics Cloud, you can access it via the left panel from the New Side Menu. My Metrics is broken down into three simple areas:

  1. Your Metrics: A collection of all performance cards you have created or that have been shared with you. You may manage this collection by refreshing the list, modifying the variance display, sorting the cards, or deleting entries. See below manage your list section.
  2. Detailed Visualization: When you select a metric, a chart instantly visualizes its data. The type of chart can be set during the creation of the metric. You can also see exactly which filters are currently applied.
  3. Smart Insights: Go beyond the chart with an automated analysis that reveals hidden patterns and important observations in your data.

Create and Edit Your Metrics List

There are several ways to create a new list. You can do so from the My Metrics page or from the chart‚Äôs menu within a story (optimized design experience). Let‚Äôs explore those options in details.

Create a List from the My Metrics Page:

From the side navigation, select My Metrics and, from the list view drop-down, choose Create New Metrics List. In the creation dialog, enter the list details, only the name is mandatory, though a description is recommended to clarify the types of metrics to be included. Optionally select a folder to organize the list, then choose Save to commit your changes.

Create a List from Story:

Open the story (optimized design experience) that contains the chart data point you want to monitor, then choose Add to Metrics List from the chart‚Äôs context menu. In the Add to Metrics List dialog, set Add Metric to: Create New Metrics List, and in the Create New Metrics List dialog provide the list details, only the name is required, although a description is recommended to clarify the types of metrics to be saved. Optionally select a folder to organize the list, then choose Save to commit your changes.

Rename a Metric in Your List:

Once a list has been created, you have the option to rename metrics in a list when you have access to edit. From the side navigation, select My Metrics, open the relevant list, and select the metric you wish to rename. Then open the ¬∞¬∞¬∞ More menu and choose Rename, enter the new name, and select Save.

Copy, Move, Add, or Jump to Original:

At least one metric card must be present in the list to enable certain options in the More menu. You may edit a list by copying or moving metrics to other lists. If you have access to a shared metrics list or an individually shared metric, you can add those metrics to your own list as links. You may also navigate to the original story chart.

Delete a Metric from Your List:

A metric may be deleted by its owner or by a user granted Full Control on an individually shared metric. Deleting a metric removes it from the list and permanently deletes its content.

To delete a metric, select My Metrics from the side navigation and open the list containing the metric. From the More menu, choose Delete from Metrics List, then confirm by selecting Delete in the warning dialog.

Add to Your Metrics List

We believe powerful features should be effortless to use. While analyzing data within a story built on the Optimized Design Experience, you can now right-click on the chart widget or on specific data points to add to your personal Metrics List instantly.

‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Table and Geo Map widgets are not yet supported

How to Add a Metric to Your List?

First, open the menu on any supported chart by right‚Äëclicking a data point or clicking the More Actions (¬∞¬∞¬∞) icon, then select Add to Metrics List. In the pop‚Äëup window, choose a Metrics List, pick a recent one, browse for an existing list, or create a new list, and enter a clear Metric Name so you can easily recognize it later. You can click Save to add the Metric without needs for editing.                                                                                    

Configure Your Metric:

Click Edit Metric Details to review your filters, further customize the chart, or add a comparison. Review the data card details, see which filters are applied (for example, accounts, dimensions, or cross calculations).

In the Comparison section, select Add Comparison to configure how variance is calculated and displayed for the metric. The interface provides recommended comparisons, most commonly time-based (for example, week‚Äëover‚Äëweek, month‚Äëover‚Äëmonth, or year‚Äëover‚Äëyear) or version‚Äëbased (for example, Actual vs Strategic Plan Budget) which are suggested automatically based on the chart‚Äôs date fields, filters, and any version or release metadata. You can accept a recommended option or create a custom comparison from your choice.

(Optional) Under the Display Options, add in your own footer label for the variance and modify other general display options of the metric card, such as inverting the color. For example, when your variance value has a higher expense than the predicted value. It makes sense to invert the color to red since an increase in value is not a positive sign.                         

Configure Your Detailed Visualization:

Click Next to review the Chart Visualization Details. In this step you can select a chart type that best communicates your analysis: choose trend-oriented visuals such as line, area, or column charts for comparison analyses, and composition visuals such as stacked bars, 100% stacked bars, or pie charts to show how parts contribute to a whole. Some chart options will be locked because they would fundamentally change the original data points or aggregations you selected when adding the metric to the list (for example, altering the primary aggregation, dimension, or granularity).               

When you're happy with it, click Save. Your new Metric card will be added to your Metrics List.

Manage Your Metrics Lists

You can manage your Metrics Lists and metrics cards by:

  • Reloading Your List: Refresh your list to display the latest updates to your cards. This option is usually found in the ‚ÄúMore‚Äù settings.

  • Adjusting Variance Display: Customize how card variance differences are shown. Through the ‚ÄúMore‚Äù settings, you can choose to display these differences as a percentage or an absolute value.
  • Undoing or Redoing Changes: Easily revert or reapply your most recent actions within the list, such as renaming items, reordering cards, or changing variance display settings.
  • Sorting Cards: Organize your cards using several options:
    • Default (Custom): Applies if you‚Äôve set a specific custom order.
    • Recently Added: The standard sort order if no custom sort is active.
    • A-Z / Z-A: Alphabetical sorting.

Share Your Lists and Individual Metrics

You can share your individual metrics or entire Metrics List with other stakeholders. When sharing, you have the ability to manage access levels, offering options such as view, edit, full control, or custom permissions. Additionally, you can send an email notification to users when you share with them.

Share Individual Metric:

Shared metrics are automatically saved to the Individually Shared Metrics list, which is maintained by SAP. When sharing a metric, you may specify the level of access to grant each recipient.

Open the desired metrics list in My Metrics, open the metric card and choose ¬∞¬∞¬∞ More > Share. In the Share Metric dialog, specify recipients by searching for users or by selecting Add users or teams, then choose the appropriate permissions from the Access drop-down: View, Edit, or Full control, or select Custom to configure granular permissions (for example, permit sharing but disallow deletion). Optionally enable Email new recipients to notify users, and then select Share to apply the settings.

Share Entire Metrics List:

Shared lists are automatically saved to the Shared with Me section, which is administered by SAP. When sharing a list, you may specify the level of access granted to each recipient.

 Open the desired metrics list in My Metrics and select More > Share. In the Share Metrics List dialog, specify recipients by searching for users or by choosing Add users or teams, then assign permissions from the Access drop-down View, Edit, or Full Control, or select Custom to configure granular privileges (for example, allow sharing but restrict deletion). Optionally enable Email new recipients to notify them of the share, and select Share to apply the settings.

Modify Share Settings:

Modifying the share settings allows you to assign different access levels or revoke sharing permissions previously granted to teams or individual users.

To modify sharing settings, select the metric or list, choose More > Share, then in the Share dialog select the users you wish to remove and click Unselect; you may then make further adjustments or close the dialog to finalize the changes. 

What‚Äôs Next

A forthcoming My Metrics enhancement will enable users to subscribe to scheduled metrics reports, to keep tracking changes in your metrics list by defining the recurrence pattern.

Please consult the official SAP Analytics Roadmap for a comprehensive overview of forthcoming features.

entry.title: Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application
entry.content:
Building and Deploying Custom Joule Skills for a CAP-Based Fiori Application and Integrating with SAP Build Work Zone


In this tutorial, we will guide you through the process of creating a custom Joule skill tailored to a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) based Fiori application. You‚Äôll learn how to deploy this skill and enable Joule functionality within SAP Build Work Zone, enabling intelligent, conversational interaction within your enterprise apps.

Step 1: Configure a Destination in Your SAP BTP Subaccount

Begin by setting up a destination in your SAP BTP subaccount where Joule Studio is subscribed. This destination should point to the endpoint of your CAP service.

Ensure you add the following property in the additional settings:

sap.processautomation.enabled = true

 

sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true

 

sap.build.usage = CAP

This configuration allows SAP Build to consume the service.

 

Step 2: Add Destination in the Control Tower

Next, go to the Control Tower section within the SAP Build Process Automation cockpit and add the destination you just created.

 

Step 3: Start a New Action Project

Navigate to the Actions tab and click Create to initiate a new action project.

 

Step 4: Choose SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

Since your action will interact with a CAP service, select SAP Cloud Application Programming Model as the project type.

 

Step 5: Select and Configure Service Endpoints

  • A list of available service endpoints from your CAP application will be displayed. Pick the desired endpoint and complete the necessary configuration.

 

  • Click on Next
  • Give You Project Name

 

 

  • Create Action for the ODATA Service
  • Select required endpoint and configure it.

  

 

  • Test the Endpoint with destination and see the output

 

 

  • Create similar action for the all department data and test it

 

 

 

Step 6: Build and Deploy Your Joule Skill

  • Click Create to set up the action project. Then, select the Joule Skill tile and create the skill

 

  • Open the above skill and again create joule skill and give name and description

 

  • Open he above skill and add action like below

 

  • Configure destination for this action

 

  • Configure the Output Variable for this action

 

  • Set the output variable on clicking on End
  • Create similar joule skill for department by following above steps

 

  • Once you finish, Save, Release

 

 

 

 

  • After Releasing Click on Deploy and choose the environment that you want

 

 

Step 7: Enable Shared Access

  • Go to home page and click on Control Tower
  • Choose Environment
  • Select Environment that we choose for our Joule Skill you will see your deployed skill there

 

 

  • Click on Setting and Enable shared option

Step 8: Connect Joule with SAP Build Work Zone

At the global account level, access the Formations area. Select Include Systems and add SAP Build Work Zone from the appropriate subaccount.

Activate these features:

  • Enable Joule Icon in Integrated System

 

Step 9: Confirm Integration and Activate Joule

Verify your setup under System Landscape ‚Üí Formation.

Then, log into your SAP Build Work Zone site.

Step 10: Validate Your Skills

Open your Work Zone site to see the Joule Icon appear at the top.

 

Test your deployed skill by typing queries related to your CAP application and observe how Joule responds.

 

 

 

Summary

Integrating custom Joule Skills into SAP Build Work Zone allows you to embed conversational AI directly within your business applications. This guide demonstrated how to connect a CAP-based Fiori app, configure necessary destinations, deploy custom skills, and enable Joule for seamless interaction.

By following these steps, you enable end users to engage naturally with enterprise data and processes‚Äîmaking your applications smarter, more interactive, and easier to use.

entry.title: Re: Is there any API in sap public cloud to read the full...
entry.content:
Hello @ManuelDias 

Thanks for your detailed follow-up. I reviewed the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Finance documentation regarding your need to read the full Journal Entry XML, including <Tax> and <ProductTaxItem> tags.

Supported features and functionalities

  • The API Journal Entry - Post (Synchronous) enables inbound posting of full journal entries, including header, item structure, and tax tags.  SAP Business Accelerator Hub-Post journal entries synchronously from external systems to your system--Journal Entry - Post (Synchronous)
  • The APIS Journal EntryPost (Asynchronous) and Journal Entry Change Asynchronous are also documented for inbound processing of JEs. SAP Community/APIs for Journal Entries ‚Äì The Collection(updated July 2025)
  • The API Journal Entry Item Read (A2X) lets you extract item-level data via OData. SAP Help Portal-Operational Journal Entry Item - Read (A2X)
  • The documentation states that the Journal Entry node contains all general journal entry information as well as item nodes. SAP Help Portal-APIs for General Ledger Accounting-Journal Entry

Hope it helps,

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: What I Wish I Knew
entry.content:
There are many things I wish I had known when I started my journey with SAP, but the biggest thing would be I wish I had access to an easy-to-use dictionary of SAP-specific nomenclature. There are a lot of things that make sense once you're immersed in the SAP world, but the first time you hear something like "S4/HANA", it has no real-world context.

 

There also some - let's say "unique" - SAP user interface design decisions that would have been nice to have highlighted when starting. Mostly because SAP application interfaces often behave differently than you may expect if you've used other desktop or web applications. This stuff is not super hard to learn, and you do get used to it, but when starting out it goes against decades of muscle memory (e.g. an "accept" or "cancel/reject" button often not being where you'd expect it to be).

entry.title: Returning to ASUG After 10 Years: Join Me at ASUG Tech Connect 2025
entry.content:
Ten years. That's how long it's been since I last attended an ASUG event back in 2015. As I prepare to head to Louisville, Kentucky for ASUG Tech Connect 2025 (November 4‚Äì6), I find myself excited to reconnect with old friends and making new connections in the SAP Community after a decade-long gap.

This time, I'm returning in my role as Product Manager for SAP LeanIX solutions , ready to share the latest innovations in enterprise architecture management and automated discovery capabilities with you.

What I'll Be Presenting

I'm thrilled to be (co-)running three sessions at the event, each designed to give you hands-on experience with the latest developments in SAP LeanIX:

Session 1: SAP LeanIX Solutions: Powering Transformation and Connecting IT to Business

Learn about the latest product developments in SAP LeanIX and what they mean for your enterprise architecture practice.

Session 2: Hands-on Lab: Navigating Transformations with the Integrated Toolchain

This session is purely interactive and hands-on for participants. Explore how SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio, and SAP Cloud ALM work together to enable organizations to drive smarter decision-making and accelerate digital transformation projects.

Session 3: SAP Signavio and SAP LeanIX Roadmap Overview and Deep Dive

Dive into the integrated product roadmap of SAP Signavio and SAP LeanIX, engineered to enable cross-functional collaboration across enterprise architecture, process management, and transformation initiatives.

 

Besides these sessions, you can find me at the SAP booth and connect with me via the ASUG Events app. Furthermore, you can now book your Expert 1:1 appointment with me. As part of these talks, I‚Äôd love to particularly discuss ‚Äúmy‚Äù two favorite roadmap items on https://roadmap.leanix.net/

  • ‚ÄúSAP landscape discovery: Discover context to self-built software deployed to SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime‚Äù: Let me share the latest updates on its developments.
  • ‚ÄúApplication Discovery: Discover classic on-stack SAP ERP extensions‚Äù: I love to discuss the problems SAP LeanIX can address in this context and which jobs-to-be-done might help your transformation journey.

Fresh from SAP TechEd Berlin: The AI Agent Hub

I closely work with my colleague Michelle and thus can share details related to her blog post on the AI agent hub. It will be covered in my presentations, too, and I am happy to elaborate more 1:1.

Reconnecting and New Connections

After 10 years away from ASUG events, I'm eager to reconnect with the friends and connections I made in the past. But equally important, I want to make new connections with enterprise architects who are tackling today's challenges‚Äîfrom clean core strategies to AI governance, from cloud migrations to business transformation.

The SAP community has always been about learning from each other, and I'm looking forward to hearing your stories, challenges, and successes.

entry.title: Re: "failed connecting company's data base" error when st...
entry.content:
I had the same issue on one computer.  The fix for me was to update the ODBC driver to the one that matches the server.  Typically ODBC Driver 17 and SQL 2019 are the compatible versions. 

SQL 2022 and ODBC Driver 18 are compatible, if you are on that version. 

The workstation had a driver lower than 17,  after updating to 17,  I set all addons to manual temporarily, ran the SAP client as admin, turned on all of the addons, one by one and had no issue.  Subsequently closed SAP, changed the addons to automatic again and logged in normally to SAP and the user no longer has the error.  The user can log in normally and everything loads correctly.

entry.title: Can we use TOGAF style of EA and still be Agile?
entry.content:
Can we use TOGAF[1] and still be Agile?

Can we use at the same time SAFe[2] and still have well-organized Enterprise Architecture practice?

Why am I putting TOGAF and SAFe next to each other, at the first place? They are not frameworks covering the same "matter"...

Who is who...

Indeed. TOGAF is ‚Äúonly‚Äù Enterprise Architecture framework, it‚Äôs iterative by its nature and it does not  imply (at least not formally), nor prescribe, nor exclude whether we use i.e. Design Thinking to come to desired TO-BE design, or we use i.e. "classical"  Waterfall or perhaps "modern" Agile and DevOps to migrate and implement.  An organization can chose its own model of designing, delivery and operations, as long as TOGAF ADM (The Architecture Development Method) is on ‚Äútop‚Äù of it.

On the other hand, SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework) is an Agile framework, built for use in large enterprises. It does embrace the role of Architecture including Enterprise Architect (as opposed to some other Agile frameworks). SAFe does not explicitly exclude use of ‚Äúother‚Äù EA frameworks, but it does positions itself as an ‚Äúumbrella‚Äù ‚Äì organizing not only DevOps part, but design part as well.

There is some obvious overlapping:.

  • Both are defining the use of Requirements Management, but this is quite normal. 
  • Both are defining the role of the IT Architecture, although SAFe is not defining ‚Äúhow to‚Äù design or architect solutions.

However, these overlapping are not critical and this by itself is not limiting use of one vs. the other framework.  What is making things difficult, when trying to put them together, is their  "nature":

  • Both TOGAF and SAFe tend to ‚Äúarrange‚Äù and ‚Äúorganize‚Äù flow of thoughts around themselves ‚Äì they both expect the control. 

Value proposition?

Remember, we are in the age of the Continuous Transformation[3] ‚Äì everything around us is very much disruptive and VUCA[4].  Sometimes we need to adopt, if we want to climb the mountain, One size does not fit all... 

Figure 1. Continuous Transformation

What is the value of having TOGAF and SAFe working together? Let's put it in this way:  

  1. TOGAF can give us structure avoiding "hasty" decision; but SAFe will ensure we are not being too slow ‚Äì when more agility is needed.
  2. SAFe can bring flexibility of self-organized Agile teams; but TOGAF can help us control how fast we are travelling ‚Äì so we do not lose the control.
  3. Both TOGAF and SAFe can complement each other, in its own way, in bringing Business Value ‚Äì but with focus on immediate needs. TOGAF will better ‚Äúsee‚Äù the horizon, while SAFe will have better ‚Äúview‚Äù on the mountain ahead of us.

I know it sounds a bit controversial, but it actually could make sense. Even though these frameworks are not covering the same "matter", they might act as balance to each other... If we can make them work "together" perhaps we can benefit from "both" Worlds...   

How do we do it?

If I can choose one thing which could connect both, its DevOps!

  • DevOps can be a ‚Äúglue‚Äù connecting structured Architecture with the infinite loop of development and operations.
  • DevOps does not even care how we organize our ‚Äúdesign‚Äù,
  • Both TOGAF and SAFe are quite ‚Äúhappy‚Äù to have DevOps on board‚Ä¶ 

 

Figure 2. DevOps as a glue

We need to accept the fact there is no ‚Äúboss‚Äù ‚Äì TOGAF philosophy and SAFe Agile Manifesto must work side-by-side.

  • Long-term IT Strategy will be built through structured TOGAF process.
  • Work will be organized with SAFe Agile teams and ceremony.
  • TOGAF ADM has its place when it comes to strategic initiatives as well ‚Äì but must move aside when ‚Äúquick‚Äù wins are needed.

Not easy, but doable‚Ä¶

And it can bring the value ‚Äì if we can put ‚Äúthem‚Äù together. 

Acknowledgment

*)  Images creation was supported by Gen AI.

References

[1] TOGAF: https://www.opengroup.org/togaf 

[2] SAFe: https://framework.scaledagile.com/ 

[3] Continuous Transformation: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/enterprise-architecture-in-the-era-of-agile/ba-p/224058 

[4] VUCA: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-discussions/enterprise-architecture-in-the-time-of-vuca/m-p/14122118

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About SAP Discovery Center Before TechEd
entry.content:
SAP TechEd 2025 is approaching‚Äîthe premier annual event for SAP developers, solution architects, and IT professionals worldwide. With thousands of sessions, hands-on workshops, and networking opportunities waiting for you, success at TechEd depends on how well-prepared you arrive. That's where the SAP Discovery Center's latest updates come in. 

From a comprehensive SAP AI Return-On-Investment (ROI) calculator that provides real-time financial justification for AI packages to an enhanced SAP BTP Guidance Framework that serves as your star map to best practices, these updates, these updates directly address the challenges you face every day: proving value, reducing implementation risk, and accelerating digital transformation timelines.

Whether you're a solution architect planning your next SAP Business Technology Platform implementation, a developer exploring AI possibilities, or an IT leader who needs to justify technology investments with hard numbers, the new SAP Discovery Center features will become your most valuable pre-TechEd preparation. Let's dive into what's new, why it matters, and how you can leverage these tools to maximize your TechEd experience and drive immediate value back to your organization.

AI on SAP Discovery Center

1. Enhanced AI Catalogue: Your Complete AI Solution Navigator

The SAP Business AI Catalogue has received a major upgrade that transforms how you explore and evaluate AI solutions. The catalogue now features dedicated categories for "Joule" and "AI Agent", making it easier than ever to find the specific AI capabilities you need for your organization.

Major Enhancements:

  • The catalogue now reflects SAP's new per-user-per-month commercial model, providing transparent pricing visibility
  • AI packages that bundle AI agents and features alongside consumption-based AI agents and features for flexible implementation options
  • Comma-separated value (CSV) export functionality allows you to download the entire AI catalogue for offline analysis, team sharing, and integration with your procurement processes

üîóExplore the enhanced AI Catalogue: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-catalog/

 

2. Streamlined Discovery with Intelligent Filtering

The completely redesigned filters improve the experience of searching through SAP Discovery Center‚Äôs AI offerings. The updated interface and enhanced look-and-feel make finding relevant offerings faster and more efficient.

Key Improvements:

  • Smart filters help you pinpoint AI offerings that match your specific use cases, industry, and technical requirements
  • At-a-glance information on catalogue cards provides essential details without requiring deep navigation
  • Improved user experience that reduces time-to-insight and accelerates your AI exploration journey

 

3. ROI-Driven Decision Making with the AI Estimator

The new Return-on-Investment (ROI) calculation feature added to the AI Estimator transforms how organizations evaluate and justify AI investments. With the ROI estimation, users can make more informed decisions on AI packages and consumption-based AI offerings.

Game-Changing Capabilities:

  • Real-time ROI calculations for both AI packages and consumption-based AI offerings
  • Transparent methodology that explains how ROI estimates are calculated, building confidence in your investment decisions
  • Business case support that provides the financial justification needed for executive approval and budget allocation

üîóCalculate your AI ROI: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-estimator-v1

 

4. Integrated AI and SAP BTP Service Connections

The enhanced SAP BTP Service Catalogue with clear linkage between AI offerings and SAP BTP services now shows exactly which AI offerings relate to specific services, providing comprehensive visibility into how AI capabilities can amplify your existing SAP BTP investments.

Revolutionary Features:

  • Direct AI offering visibility within SAP BTP service detail pages eliminates the guesswork in finding relevant AI capabilities
  • Improved use case planning and implementation by understanding how AI can enhance your existing SAP BTP services, and with clear connections between the AI foundation and AI capabilities

üîóExplore integrated AI offerings: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/serviceCatalog/sap-build-process-automation?region=all&tab=relatedaiofferings

Other Updates on SAP Discovery Center

1. SAP BTP Guidance Framework: Your Architecture Star Map

The new SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a resource that extends the scope for architects by providing comprehensive methodologies, guidance, and architecture content. This framework serves as your guide toward architecting, developing, and deploying enterprise-grade solutions on SAP BTP.

What Makes This Framework Essential:

  • Structured adoption phases provide clear direction and a proven approach for adopting SAP BTP according to industry best practices
  • Tailored recommendations drive your organization's SAP BTP maturity through an integrated maturity assessment
  • Strategic decision support helps you make the right decisions at the right time, maximizing value from your SAP BTP investments
  • Comprehensive guidance covers everything from initial planning to advanced enterprise implementations

This framework is particularly valuable for SAP TechEd attendees who want to move beyond tactical implementations to strategic, enterprise-scale SAP BTP adoption.

üîóAccess the BTP Guidance Framework: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/guidance-framework

 

2.  Events: Expanding the SAP Discovery Center Knowledge Universe

The SAP Discovery Center homepage now features a dedicated Events section. This new section serves as a centralized resource for hands-on events designed for both SAP customers and partners, adding another dimension to the Discovery Center's comprehensive learning ecosystem.

Partner and Customer Benefits:

  • Hands-on learning opportunities help customers and partners deepen their knowledge and enhance their technical skills
  • Knowledge transfer that benefits the entire ecosystem by making expertise more accessible to all audiences
  • Networking opportunities connect partners with SAP experts and fellow practitioners
  • Customer value enhancement through access to more knowledgeable, qualified partners
  • Ecosystem strengthening by making partner enablement more visible and accessible
  • Accelerated adoption through joint events that align partner capabilities with customer needs and use cases

üîóDiscover partner events: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/index.html#

 

3.  Latest Mission Releases: Learning That Drives Results

The SAP Discovery Center continues to expand its mission-based learning portfolio with five new missions that address the most pressing enterprise challenges:

üöÄActivate Joule with SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP)
üöÄSetup of Joule in Mobile Start
üöÄAccelerate Smart Supplier Selection with Retrieval-Augmented Generative AI
üöÄMigrate data from SAP Business One to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
üöÄAccelerate your BTP Journey with FRE Acceleration Datasphere Pack

These hands-on experiences provide practical, implementable knowledge that bridges the gap between theoretical understanding and real-world application, ensuring both partners and customers can immediately leverage cutting-edge SAP technologies.

How Missions Guide Your Journey: 

  • Hands-on learning experiences that provide practical skills through guided, interactive tutorials and real-world scenarios
  • Self-paced exploration allows partners and customers to learn at their own speed and revisit content as needed
  • Comprehensive skill development covering beginner to advanced topics across SAP's entire technology portfolio
  • Immediate practical application with step-by-step guidance that can be implemented directly in production environments  
  • Reduced learning curve for new SAP technologies through expert-designed tutorials and best practices

üîó Explore all new missions: https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missioncatalog

 

SAP Business Technology Platform ‚Äì Priority Use Cases

Explore the comprehensive range of SAP Business Technology Platform use cases that these missions support here:

üîóhttps://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/use-cases.html?sort=latest_desc

 

Your Next Steps

As you prepare for SAP TechEd 2025, think of these tools as your spacecraft's vital systems: the ROI Calculator as your fuel efficiency monitor, ensuring every investment delivers maximum propulsion; the SAP BTP Guidance Framework as your star maps, guiding you safely through complex architectural decisions; and the Events as your communication array, keeping you connected with the broader SAP ecosystem of knowledge and expertise.

The countdown to SAP TechEd has begun. Your mission parameters are set. These SAP Discovery Center updates aren't just features‚Äîthey're your launch sequence for achieving breakthrough results. Whether you're embarking on your first SAP BTP expedition or you're a seasoned space traveller ready for advanced AI exploration, you now have everything needed for a successful mission.

 

Ready for liftoff to transform your SAP journey?

entry.title: Regarding Prefilling Customer Data in Emarsys Forms
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

I‚Äôd like to check if it‚Äôs possible to prefill customer data into Emarsys Forms, so that customers don‚Äôt have to manually enter their information.

Could you please confirm if this functionality is supported and advise on how it can be implemented?

 

Thank you in advance.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Regarding Prefilling Customer Data in Emarsys Forms
entry.content:
Hi,

 

This can be done by following the steps below based on KBA 3530893 - How to prefill Change Profile form with contact master data? - SAP for Me:

 

You can insert form link in follow format into email content, then this form will be prefilled with contact master data in Emarsys if contact opens it from inbox email.

https://<form link domain>/u/register.php?par={{contact.uid}}_$cid$_$llid$_1_t_<account id>_<form id>

 

You need to replace <form link domain>, <account id> and <form id> parts of URL in Cause part. And you can get them from form preview.

For example, following URL is the form preview one:

https://goto.lifestylelabels.com/u/register.php?CID=213802546&session_id=33c5Wc7kCY1k37121887&f=100005987

Then the mapping is like:

  • <form link domain> -> "goto.lifestylelabels.com"
  • <account id> -> "213802546"
  • <form id> -> "100005987"

You can get the URL to be used in Email content:

https://goto.lifestylelabels.com/u/register.php?par={{contact.uid}}_$cid$_$llid$_1_t_213802546_100005987

 

Best regards,

SAP Technical Support

entry.title: Unable to Create New Field Selection Key in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
The issue involves the inability to modify the field status (e.g., mandatory, optional, etc.) in the Field Selection Key for purchase order types in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. User seeks confirmation on whether it is possible to create a new Field Selection Key in the SAP public cloud system and requests guidance on how to achieve this.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Create New Field Selection Key in SAP Publi...
entry.content:
Hi,

Please note there is no SSCUI entry to change the Field Properties on Purchase Orders or Purchase Requisitions. If the user wants to mark the fields as hidden, optional, or mandatory there is no configuration entry with this purpose, but this functionality is delivered through BAdIs to give more flexibility on the Logic for Field control.

Refer to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003268822

Best regards,

SAP Support
